Award.AwardTitle: Niche Versus Neutral Structure in Populations and Communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
The development of neutral theory has had a profound influence on our understanding of the dynamics of genes, cells, populations and communities by illuminating the case in which types are of equal fitness and hence random or chance events have predominant influence. In particular, neutral theory provides a null model whose failures indicate when mechanisms other than chance are important. However, biologists still lack a way of testing neutral theory that clearly identifies the trait differences driving any specialization or differentiation that exists. The goal of this project is to explore a novel idea for testing neutral theory, using patterns of species' richness, relative abundance, and phylogeny along trait axes. If tangible, the resulting theory would both clearly identify important trait differences, and be robust to uncertainty and complexity in both the population and community contexts.

Results from this project could set the stage for a great deal of future work aimed at gaining an understanding of the mechanisms maintaining diversity in specific systems, knowledge that is vital to our ability to manage, conserve, and restore our biological resources. In addition, the investigators will work to encourage the participation of women in mathematical biology by running a focus group on topics related to the research at a summer camp for girls organized by the Women in Science and Engineering program at the University of Michigan. Finally, the PI will integrate the research into General Ecology and Population and Community Ecology courses, and make teaching materials available on-line.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What mechanisms maintain diversity in populations and communities?  Do different types coexist because they are simply of equal ability in a given environment, or because they differ in the niches they exploit?  If the latter, what key trait differences drive this niche differentiation?  The development of neutral theory in biology has had a profound influence on our understanding of the structure and dynamics of populations and communities by providing insight in to the case where types are of equal in ability in the local environment and hence chance birth and death events is the dominant influence.  In particular, neutral theory provides a null model whose failures indicate when mechanisms other than chance have an important influence.  Departures from neutral theory are widely used by evolutionary biologists as indicators of directional selection.  However, as of yet, biologists lack a way of testing neutral theory that clearly identifies the trait differences driving any niche differentiation (i.e. frequency-dependent selection) that exists.  Furthermore, in the community context ecologists lack a way of testing neutral theory that is robust to uncertainties about the demography of the community as a whole (such as historical changes in size, or the degree of dispersal limitation experienced by the regional pool of species).  

 This project has made considerable advances towards a robust approach to inferring the presence of niche differentiation from patterning in the relative abundance of species or types as a function of the variation in traits among them that is enabling stable coexistence. It has significantly advanced our theory of how communities are structured when stable coexistence through niche differentiation is at play. Prior theory of this structure ignored the potential effects of chance events and immigration and predicted even spacing in trait space among species stably coexisting. We studied models including chance effects and immigration along with niche differences, and instead find that a pattern of emergent clusters of species along trait axes is expected. We also proposed a metric for finding this pattern in data and showed its success in detecting the presence of niche differentiation whenever it is having an important impact on community dynamics. With one exception, there is no systematic way this qualitative pattern could arise from demographic complexities other than niche differentiation, hence the approach of looking for this pattern is quite robust. The one exception to this is the potential for mutation or speciation to lead to this pattern at large scales. This arises because parent and daughter types or species tend to be similar in traits, and hence historically abundant types will have had time and force to produce many daughter types or species nearby in trait space. We have also studied and highlighted this potential source of clustering in this project. However, we have also highlighted that this cause for local scale pattern can be ruled out through examination of, or by informing the neutral model with, data on species’ abundances in the regional pool. This project has also made advances in the development of neutral models to be used as process-based null models for the detection of a variety of ecological processes.

 Understanding the coexistence of species on the landscape is essential for human society to manage and conserve its biological resources on this planet. This project has made significant theoretical advances that have improved ecologists’ ability to gain this understanding using observations of nature.

 This project has also encouraged and broadened the participation of women and minorities in mathematical biology. Towards this aim, for two summers we ran a focus group on ecology with an emphasis on the use of mathematics and computer programming at a summer camp for girls organized by the Women in Science and Engineering program at the University of Michigan. The girls that participated gave our focus group very positive reviews, and one later returned to do an internship in the lab as a highschool student. In addition, this grant supported one native American female postdoctoral fellow and one female Principle Investigator in their research in mathematical biology.
